Мені б дуже хотілося рекомендувати цю гру, мені подобається астрономічна тематика, але, на жаль, ця гра якась дуже неоптимізована та 600 грн то занадто для неї... Інструментарій мізерний, і деякими моментами гра нереалістична: наприклад, якщо прибрати зірку, то планети все одно освічуються так, ніби нічого не прибирали (при тому, що підсвічування планет вимкнено). Типу... кхм. І у мене навіть кіберпанк на ультра не лагав так, як ця гра, хоча мій пк відповідає системним вимогам. Через деякий час гра зависає, настільки довго, що єдиним рішенням є вирубити її через диспетчер... грати майже неможливо. Я б хотіла засісти в ній надовго, але з цими зависаннями та лагами це прям некомфортно. 
Коротше, розчарована, треба дууже потужний комп для цього.

185590399.review:
Universe Sandbox is amazing as a sandbox to doodle with, as an educational tool, and as a worldbuilding aid.

There are some aspects I wish were more in-depth or flexible, e.g. landmass drawing. However this is never going to a “finite game” that will be completed one day. It's a simulator that involves a bunch of data and science so there will always be room for improvement by definition. I really admire the work that was put into it for those reasons and I will look forward to its development!

185496089.review:
[b]After playing for 90+ hours, unfortunately, I cannot recommend Universe Sandbox 2 in its current state because of "forced" simulation gameplay mechanics, extreme lack of QoL features, and unresolved bugs making the simulator unstable.[/b]

[h2] What Universe Sandbox 2 succeeds at simulating: [/h2]

The biggest mechanic you can experiment with in Universe Sandbox 2 is make a multitude of explosions, dust clouds, black holes, and nebulae with a simple "add X item" mechanic. Make "cold" stars, make bizarre orbits of random planets, turn Mars into Earth, turn Earth into Venus, and then do slightly more complex stuff such as simulating a Red Giant phase (of our Sun in a bugged state). That's really it. I've created around 8 solar systems with this game and a Black Hole "solar system" out of entertainment.

[h2] What Universe Sandbox 2 Struggles with (There's a lot): [/h2]

[u][b]This Simulator has zero features for organically made solar systems [/b][/u]

Something I wanted to try when I first got this game was to use gas clouds, rocks, and form a solar system from scratch and let time form planets using gravity and mass. [u]You can't do that in this game.[/u] In US2, [i]rock particles[/i] regardless of size are never attracted to each other and barely interact with planetoid objects. Unless if you force a rock particle to hit a planet using the "launch" feature (which has a chance of completely obliterating the height map and even the planet). You can't load in elements orbiting a star and expect gravity to LAND onto said planets. 

US2 forces you to plop in Blank Planets or Random Planets into your custom solar system and then edit the material data from there. I like how there are albedo and atmosphere settings which allows for experimentation (like having a warm object far away from a star). 

[u][b]Object customization is severely lacking and the existing features become stale after a few simulations[/b][/u]

On the Macro scale, US2 is incredible at handling black holes and supernovae. Stars feel mostly complete, but there really needs to be an option to allow stars to convert their Hydrogen into Helium to simulate a star's life cycle. 
That being said, customization features for objects such as planets, moons, comets (MIA), space stations, and planet habitability are [u]significantly lacking.[/u] 

The features you are provided for terrestrial objects is a basic "circle" tool that raises/lowers the height map, a tool to change the sea level, atmosphere modifications, an atmosphere converter for those looking to create Earth-like planets ([b] this is a good feature!)[/b] and a handful of cloud and elevation colors/textures to make a few unique planets.
[u]But where are the height map importing tools? Where are other elements and solid materials we can choose from? Why does vegetation look like paint when we have that feature on the planets? How about custom city light maps or custom textures? What about different weather patterns for planets and moons or perhaps tides that are affected by satellites? Why are we only limited to three colors per terrestrial object?[/u].

The same can be said for gas giants. I love the custom band feature, but [u]what about storms or cosmetic rings?*[/u].
I took a peak at Discord and found many users trying to share their custom planets, many of them load US2 with game-slowing mods to achieve the results. If Universe Sandbox 2 had more features, the game would be more enjoyable after a few hours.
 
[u][b]Material, Temperature, Pressure, Collision, and Lighting bugs CRIPPLE gameplay [/b][/u]

Oh boy, where do I start...

MATERIALS: there's a chance that adding a material won't spawn or spawn incorrectly. This especially happens with helium. Sometimes using the "add new materials" feature causes a planet to flicker.

TEMPERATURE: In order to [u]properly[/u] stabilize an object's temperature, you must set your sim's speed to around 50 years a second. Using the in-game stabilize temperature feature makes a part of the planet -459 degrees [b]which is not a bug according to the developers.[/b]

[i]Review Update: Temperatures of atmosphere-lacking bodies have warm nights when they should be very cold. Any kind of elevation above 10km can turn an extremely warm planet to absolute zero very quickly[/i].

PRESSURE: Materials such as H20, C02, and Nitrogen have fixed (and slightly inaccurate) melting/boiling/freezing points. Increasing the ATM of an object [b]DOES NOT[/b] increase a material's boiling point [strike]even though there's a built-in phase diagram[/strike]. If an object has a pressure of 5 ATM or higher, I'd expect it to allow liquid C02 to exist at the right temperature instead of quickly evaporating. The same can be said for water. Want a pressure cooker planet? Too bad!

COLLISION: [b]Arguably the worst offender of the bunch[/b]. If the sim's speed is faster than 20 days a second, there is a 100% CHANCE that moons and rings will fling lightyears away from your solar system, leaving you to catch and save them to your toolbox! Moons commonly defy the laws of gravity regardless of accuracy setting and become its own planet. Because gravity is bugged (as I said earlier, planets don't attract objects properly), you cant expect gravity to fix your situation.
Planets with more than a single moon are [b]guaranteed[/b] to encounter a gravity issue unless if your sim speed is incredibly slow (boring!). The same applies to rings. Rings are basically the same rock particle objects that are just as capable of flinging lightyears into space as moons. 

LIGHTING: Why can I see every moon and object that is 50 AU away from another object? And why can't I see anything but my star in "realistic" mode? The lack of lighting and visibility features hurts the simulator's realism. When landing on a planet, your star will become completely black as if it's eclipsed. Increasing the light intensity even by a slight amount will turn brighter-colored objects blindingly white, even when said object is super far away from its light source. 
[b]However, Universe Sandbox 2 does an incredible job handling multiple light sources and colors. This feature works well.[/b]

[h2]Conclusion: [/h2]
Universe Sandbox 2 can offer so much more than [b]SPHERE GO B00M B00M!![/b]. While the simulator feels complete with macro-level objects, Universe Sandbox 2 is an [u]empty desert[/u] when it comes to the world-building side where players can unleash their creativity and interests in astronomy. Pesky bugs will turn any object that isn't a planet into a shooting star that will fling in random directions at the speed of light. The tools to customize planets is almost a decade behind other simulator games that have import tools to enhance gameplay (See: City Skylines import height map tool and texture tools).
I am concerned with the direction that the new graphics beta is heading in as the UI is buggy and many of the lighting features (light intensity for example) don't translate well. Let's also leave bloom in the mid-2000s, please. 

Even with my criticisms, I still play the game because some elements are enjoyable. If you're [u]really into astronomy[/u] and have the imagination to dump hours into simulations, I'd say it's worth it. [u]Otherwise, it's a definite pass.[/u].

185452913.developer_response:
At the time of writing, the latest full release of Universe Sandbox is Update 34.1.1. The current preview version of Update 35, which includes the Space Goggles, our new graphics, and other new features, is currently still in development and has not been fully released.

To opt into the Universe Sandbox Preview:
1. Exit Universe Sandbox
2. Right-click on the game title in your Steam Library
3. Click on ‘Properties’
4. Select the ‘Betas’ tab
5. Set the dropdown menu to ‘!preview-version’
6. Close the Properties window
7. Steam will now update Universe Sandbox to the experimental build
8. Once updated, launch Universe Sandbox

Es tut mir leid, dass Universe Sandbox auf Ihrem Computer nicht gut funktioniert. Wir möchten Ihnen dabei helfen, herauszufinden, wie wir die Leistung für Sie verbessern können.

Sie können versuchen, die Auflösung Ihres All Maps Atlas zu verringern
Startseite > Einstellungen > Leistung > Atlas-Auflösung aller Karten

Können Sie uns bitte auch eine Kopie Ihrer Player.log-Datei senden, damit wir weitere Möglichkeiten prüfen können, wie wir die Leistung für Sie verbessern können? Hier sind einige Anweisungen dazu:
http://universesandbox.com/support/emaillog

I'm sorry that Universe Sandbox is not performing well on your computer. We want to help you see how we can improve performance for you.

One thing to try is lowering your All Maps Atlas Resolution under
Home > Settings > Performance > All Maps Atlas Resolution

http://universesandbox.com/support/emaillog

Ингредиенты:

500 мл молока; 14
3 яйца; 14

0,5 ст. л. сахара; 1
0,5 ч. л. соли; 1

Взбейте яйца, соль, сахар и примерно треть молока. 1

184862130.review:
I'm very into space exploration and the solar system.
I used to LOVE this game a decade ago, but it's hot garbage now. They keep making changes to it that I don't think anyone asked for. For example, the composition of worlds is only accurate for a few (ie Earth & Mars), but they show worlds like Europa as 100% silicate, no water. Same with Ceres which is at least 25% water.

The focus in entirely on smashing thing together and the particles that creates, not on anything factual.

So in a nutshell, if you like smashing things together and don't care about accuracy then it's great.

If you want to know how things would really play out? Then it's hot garbage like I said. 

I've complained for years that the game is getting LESS user friendly but they don't seem to care.

I wish someone would make a realistic version of this, I'd buy it in a heartbeat....

184861880.review: Give me more spacussy, i want that planetussy, that galaxussy, that univerussy, that uh....that fat asstronaut??

184821714.review:
Glad I held off until 2025 to grab this... and 20 minutes of play time is enough to know that this is worth full price.

I was always curious about this Sandbox before, but with the late 2024 engine/graphical/UI update, this is a really good place to get into the game. And considering this is a game that has been in Early Access for 10 years, and just received a thorough revision like this... it is very impressive, and very promising.

UI is efficient, effective and utilitarian. It could be prettier, sure, but it is what it needs to be without stealing any more hardware resources than it needs. As a result this runs beautifully at 4K on max settings while you make major physics tweaks to your planets/systems on the fly.

The tutorial is top notch. Text based and shows you only the absolute essentials of what is, overall, a very detailed and thorough system.

It is enough to make you realise that this is what a real "Sandbox" game should look like. Total and absolute freedom, yet intelligently structured and easily accessible!

If you are into this kind of thing, especially if you are an astro/space enthusiast/nerd, it is a genuinely thought provoking experience. Messing with planetary orbits, triggering an ice age due to a distorted orbit and shooting a laser at the surface to melt the ice (this happens in the tutorial)... to playing with planetary sizes, gravitational density values, "painting water" onto a planet's surface, adding satellite/moon influences to said planets, solar systems relating to galactic physics, and so on and so on.. all immediate and real time results to your adjustments as you experiment/simulate.... very cool.

After I skimmed through the tutorial (yes, you can skim/click-spam your way through it and still learn what you need to learn)... the immediate and catastrophic experimentation I was able to provoke was very enjoyable. While the destruction and chaos is an easy itch to scratch, there is obviously a lot more you can get out of this sandbox if you are motivated to play and experiment with a real creative and scientific purpose in mind.

If you have been conditioned to follow quest way points and bleeding your life away grinding for battlepass garbage, this game is absolutely not for you.

If, on the other hand, you have an interest in games that improve you in someway, whether through reflex and tactical training or a greater technical understanding of "a thing" (the latter applying to this game), or perhaps you have a practical scientific/educational/creative set of concepts you want to play with on a planetary-to-galactic level... BUY THIS GAME!

184057402.review:
Fun simulation of planets and other large objects in space. Obviously it's not perfect by any stretch of the imagination. It's a rough simulation focusing mostly on basic newtonian gravity.
Stars and black holes aren't simulated accurately, you can't collide neutron stars and supernova are a very basic effect, which doesn't really obey the laws of physics as we know them.
You can smash Mars into Earth though and it leaves a crater, changes the atmosphere and movement of the planet. Doesn't create a moon or a even a mountain on the opposite side of the planet.
So it has lots of good stuff in already, but it's far from complete.

183625096.review:
神级天文学沙盒软件，普通人也能直观学习天体物理力学的宇宙模拟器
现在Steam上所售卖的Universe Sandbox其实是这个软件的第二代版本，我在2014年初次接触宇宙沙盘第1代，虽然以现在的眼光衡量当时的1代版本可说是相当的简陋，没有任何亮眼的视觉效果，尽管如此当时还是给我幼小的心灵以极大的震撼。
数年之后Universe Sandbox 2上架Steam，而我也是第一时间补票，2代相比1代更新了大量的物理特性、丰富的特效、比以往更丰富的模拟功能，如果你对天文学/物理学感兴趣，那么宇宙沙盒一定是你的不二之选

183578518.review: *Universe Sandbox* is a stunning space simulation game that blends education and entertainment with incredible realism. It uses advanced physics models to simulate celestial events, like the collision of galaxies or the creation of solar systems, with breathtaking accuracy. You can tweak parameters like mass, velocity, or gravitational pull and instantly see how the universe reacts, making it an interactive way to explore astrophysical principles. The visuals are mesmerizing, with detailed renderings of stars, planets, and galaxies, paired with dynamic lighting and effects that make the cosmos feel alive. Whether you're testing what would happen if Earth had two suns or simulating a black hole's impact on a nearby star, the game empowers creativity while staying grounded in real-world science. Accessible yet deep, *Universe Sandbox* is perfect for anyone curious about the universe, offering endless possibilities to explore, learn, and be inspired.

183570260.review:
Really fun messing around with planets, asteroids, stars and more. You can play with the universe and do anything you can imagine, for example you can create your own star system or see what happens if you launch the Moon at Earth.
Would give it a shot!
